journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: A numerical and experimental friction analysis of reciprocating hydraulic ‘U’ rod seals

article-meta.aff: 1Machine Elements and Tribology, University Politehnica of Bucharest, Romania
2PRIME Institute, CNRS, Mechanical Engineering, Structures and Complex Systems Department, University of Poitiers, France

author-notes.corresp: M Crudu, PRIME Institute, CNRS, Mechanical Engineering, Structures and Complex Systems Department, University of Poitiers, Poitiers, France. Email: monica.crudu@univ-poitiers.fr

abstract.p: This article is focused on the comparison between experimental and numerical friction forces obtained for a typical hydraulic ‘U’ rod seal. The numerical results are obtained by the inverse hydrodynamic lubrication method. The experimental results have been obtained on an original experimental device capable of measuring the friction force between a rod and two seals. The reciprocating rod speed, the temperature and pressure in the test cell are controlled. Despite the fact that the numerical results correspond to an idealized hydrodynamic problem for smooth surfaces, it was found that the numerical model agrees with experimental data when the predicted film thickness is higher than the rod roughness but largely lower than the seal roughness. This suggests that the roughness of the seal disappears under the pressure in the sealed contact and do not play an essential role in the lubrication mechanisms. However, it is clear that for very small film thickness, the full film lubrication theory for smooth surfaces is not convenient. This may imply that in these conditions mixed lubrication cannot be ignored or that adhesion phenomena, not taken into account by the lubrication theory, can appear in the contact areas.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hydraulic seals have always been controversial machine elements, because of their complexity and key role played in many industries such as automotive, aerospace or medicine. In the past 50 years, the number of scientific studies concerning reciprocating seals has known an important increase.

In the experimental field, White and Denny’s1 research concerning friction, leakage, wear, extrusion, roughness effect and failure mechanism for various types of hydraulic is one of the first contribution in understanding hydraulic seals functioning mechanism.

O’Donoghue and Lawrie2 continued the work of White and Denny concerning the lubrication mechanism of reciprocating seals. By testing ‘U’ type piston seal, they observed thin fluid films during instroke and thick fluid films during outstroke. They also measured the friction force and observed that the value of friction at start-ups depends on the stationary time of the system.

Kanters and Vissher3 studied the roughness effect on the friction force for a polyurethane rectangular rod seal. They tested three rods of different roughness and observed that when the rod roughness has the same order of magnitude with the seal roughness, friction increases. Such as O’Donoghue and Lawrie, they also observed differences between instroke and outstroke frictions. Instroke friction increases with the input pressure while outstroke friction is almost independent of this parameter. Another important finding of their work was a new method to determine the leakage. The method is very simple, efficient and it consists in collecting the fluid film left on the rod. They observed that the leaked fluid increases with the square root of the translational speed.

More recently, Rana et al.4 developed a test rig equipped with a microscope and computer data logging of video recorded images. Real-time images of hydrodynamic film variation for rectangular seal, gave important information concerning lubrication regime, cavitation effects, film starvation, leakage and wear. The rig also permits measurement of the friction force. They tested two roughness and speed effects on the friction. The results were in accord with those of Kanters and Vissher.3

The test rig was improved5 in order to offer more flexibility and precision in measurements. It was observed that during the first running-in period seals become smoother. Also hard fluid contaminant particles abrade the seal surface, creating microchannels that increase the leakages as the fluid is dragged out of the cylinder by this microchannels. The alimentation pressure encourages the formation of the fluid film, this being demonstrated both by direct observation and friction measurements.

In parallel with the experimental investigations, many studies have been dedicated to the numerical modelling of reciprocating seals. The evaluation of sealing performances in terms of leakage and friction is made by supposing a lubricated contact between the seal and the rod and therefore solving Reynolds equation in order to find pressure and film thickness distribution into the contact. Mainly, two distinct approaches are used in the study of hydraulic seals: the inverse hydrodynamic lubrication (IHL) and the direct methods. Exhaustive literature reviews have been published by Nau6 and more recently by Nikas.7

The main advantage of the direct method is that mixed lubrication models can be easily included in the analyses (to the authors’ knowledge, mixed lubrication models have never been used with the inverse method). The mixed lubrication conditions can be taken into account by deterministic and stochastic models. In view of the seal contact length, the stochastic approach seems more feasible. The first hypothesis in using the stochastic approach is that the pressure is calculated as a sum of the contact pressure due to asperity contact and the hydrodynamic pressure. Second, the Reynolds equation with flow factors is solved in order to include roughness effects.

Salant et al.8 and Thate and Salant9 studied both the steady state and the transient case for ‘U’ elastomeric rod seal. The transient study validates the results suggested from the steady state case analysis. The authors show the effect of the surface roughness on seal leakage and friction. It seems that their numerical results are in accord with the experimental work of Kanters, Visscher, Lawrie and O’Donoghue.

The IHL approach is based on the assumption that the dry seal-rod contact pressure distribution is equal with the pressure distribution located in the lubricated film. This fact is acceptable because the deflection of the seal due to service pressure and compression between rod and cylinder overcomes the radial strain of the seal imposed by the fluid film.

Kanters et al.10 calculates the overall film thickness for a rectangular rounded edges axisymmetric seal using the IHL approach. He applied the inverse theory to the frictionless dry contact pressure distribution, considering the influence of the boosting action in the entry region of the film. He compared the result with experimental data obtained for a polyurethane rectangular rod seal. A good correspondence was found but only for small roughness amplitudes.

Nikas et al.11 utilized the IHL approach in order to calculate the performances of a rotary vane seal. They also utilized this approach in studying the seals in transient condition.12 In this purpose, they assumed constant pressure in time for the largest part of the contact.

This article is focused on the comparison between experimental and numerical friction forces, for a typical hydraulic ‘U’ rod seal. The numerical results are obtained by the IHL approach. The initial contact pressure distribution is obtained by commercial finite element (FE) software (Abaqus) analysis. Knowing that the static FE analysis do not take into account the hydrodynamic pressure variation in the inlet region, a hydrodynamic correction is performed in order to obtain realistic results. All the details are given in ‘Model and analysis presentation’ section.

The experimental results have been obtained on an original experimental device capable of measuring the friction force between a rod and two seals. The reciprocating rod speed, the temperature and pressure in the test cell are controlled. A detailed description of the device is addressed in the ‘Experimental work’ section.

sec.title: Model and analysis presentation
sec.p:
The reciprocating rod seal is a hydraulic system element subjected to the leakage of hydraulic fluid, with consequences both on environment and on working mechanical system. The seal is mounted with an interference fit between the rod and the seal housing. The lubricant acts as a presence in the interference between the rod and the seal in order to improve the tribological and thermal behaviours of the system. The reciprocating seal mechanism has two steps: (a) the outstroke step, when the rod is moving to the left and the fluid dragged out of the cylinder adheres to the rod and (b) the instroke step, when the rod is moving to the right and the fluid is dragged back (Figure 1). The analysis is made for the steady-state case of a hydrogenated nitrile butadiene rubber (HNBR) reciprocating ‘U’ type rod seal (Figure 1). The numerical model describes the flow of the lubricant film between the rod and the seal. Figure 1.
Test seal before assembly.

sec.title: Static contact simulation
sec.p: The first step in a theoretical analysis of hydraulic seals is the evaluation of static dry pressure profile and contact length. This ‘static’ prediction is performed using an FE model (Abaqus).

The choice of the material model that predicts HNBR behaviour was made from a stress–strain curve obtained by a uniaxial tension–compression test at constant ambient temperature (20 °C) (Figure 2). It is well known that the thermal effects influence elastomers behaviour. Unfortunately, in this study, there was no opportunity to test the material at different temperature and consequently, in this article, the thermal effects are neglected.

In order to describe the seal material, several hyperelastic models implemented in Abaqus were tested. Mooney–Rivlin hyperelastic model seems to best approach the experimental data and has been used for the simulation (1)W=C10(I1-3)+C01(I2-3)+D1(J-1)2 where C10, C01, and D1 are material coefficients and J the elastic volume ratio. The values of the material coefficients, resulting from Abaqus fitting program, with a Poisson ratio of 0.49 are: C10 = −0.167, C01 = 2.85, and D1 = 7.5e−3.

In the contact regions, the seal is meshed with structured quadratic elements of 2 µm length (Figure 3). This type of elements is usually used in treating contact problems. The seal housing and the rod are treated like rigid parts. The seal is submitted at four different hydraulic pressures (palim), between 5 and 20 MPa. Figure 4 shows the contact pressure distributions obtained after the simulations. Figure 2.
HNBR stress–strain curve. HNBR: hydrogenated nitrile butadiene rubber. Figure 3.
FE model simulation of the seal assembly. FE: finite element. Figure 4.
Contact pressure distribution.

sec.title: Inverse lubrication theory
sec.p: Consequently, a simplified, one-dimensional (1D) form of the Reynolds equation is used to predict the seal behaviour (2)∂∂x(h3μ∂p∂x)=6U∂h∂x where p and h are the local pressure and film thickness in the contact, U the net sliding velocity and μ=μ0eαp the lubricant pressure dependent dynamic viscosity.

Knowing that the typical average film thickness is less than 1 µm, which imposes a hydrodynamic normal strain negligibly small in comparison with the normal strain induced by the seal interferences and the hydraulic pressure, the hydrodynamic pressure in equation (2) can be considered as equal to the dry contact pressure calculated by FE modelling. Therefore, equation (2) can be solved for the film thickness h: this is the so-called IHL theory. The authors have previously published a detailed presentation of the implementation of the IHL method in Fatu and Hajjam.13 However, for a better understanding of this article, a short reminder is given.

A first integration of equation (2) gives an algebraic 1D cubic equation in the unknown film thickness (3)h3∂p∂x=6μU(h-h0) where h0 represents the film thickness at the position where the pressure gradient is nil. In order to solve equation (3) the value of h0 must be known. The film thickness is searched in a domain inflection point A. By differentiating equation (2) and knowing that at the inflection point ∂∂x(1μ∂p∂x)=0 the film thickness at point A is (4)hA=2μU∂p∂x/A
By evaluating equation (3) at the inflection point A, the value of h0 can be written as: h0=23hA. Consequently, equation (3) can be written as (5)aH3(x)-H(x)+1=0 where H(x)=h(x)h0anda=h0 26μUdpdx

A delicate point in the implementation of the IHL method is to find a precise approximation of the inflection point A, located in the contact inlet zone. The pressure field computed directly from the structure model cannot predict the pressure generation in the gap preceding the contact area and therefore does not give a realistic approximation of the hydrodynamic pressure in this zone. Consequently, the contact pressure distributions computed by FE modelling must support a hydrodynamic correction. The film profile in the inlet zone, before the inflection point A, is given by (6)h(x)=hA+hFE(x) where hFE is the gap between the seal and the rod predicted from the FE analysis. The hydrodynamic correction is obtained by an iterative algorithm:13 direct hydrodynamic problem is used to correct the pressure distribution in the inlet zone, before the inflection point. The new pressure distribution will modify the position of the inflection points and consequently the film profile predicted by the IHL method and the spatial domain used for calculating the hydrodynamic correction for the next iteration. Several iterations are necessary to obtain a stable solution. As an example, Figure 5 shows a detailed image of the inlet region containing the pressure distribution before and after the hydrodynamic correction. Figure 5.
Zoom on the inlet zone.

Once the pressure and film thickness distribution in the contact are obtained, the friction force is computed from (7)Ff=πD∫0 Lcontact(h2·∂p∂x+μUh)dx where Lcontact is the length of the contact between the seal and the rod.

sec.title: Experimental work
sec.p: An experimental study is performed for a couple of two HNBR ‘U’ rod seals. The nominal diameter of the rod is of 25 mm.

The experimental device (Figure 6) operates in vertical position. The force sensor (3), mounted on top of the rod (1) with a threaded sleeve (2), is connected by a clamping device (4) with the test rig. The lower part of the rod passes through the test cell containing the two seals (5). As it can be observed, a relative motion between the rod and the test cell induces an instroke motion (from bottom to top) for one seal and an outstroke motion (from top to the bottom) for the other. Consequently, the recorded friction force is the combination of the outstroke friction of one seal and the instroke friction of the other seal. As the force sensor is placed on the rod, the reciprocating motion is attributed to the test cell while the rod remains in a fixed position. The test cell is mounted with a nut (6) to a sustenance device (7).This device connects the test cell with the hydraulic motor and also ensures the support of the test cell and provides the necessary space for the rod to create an operational stroke. The length of the stroke is 140 mm. The hydraulic motor provides the motion of the test cell so that the translational speed can be changed by changing the oil supply flow rate. Figure 6.
The experimental device.

The experimental device has two separate hydraulic circuits. One circuit supplies the hydraulic motor, having as components: a motor-pump actuating system, a security valve for pressure limitation, an electric servo valve that modulates the motion of the hydraulic motor rod, a hydraulic oil filter block and a displacement sensor. The other hydraulic circuit supplies the test cell. It contains a hand pump and a manometer. The experimental device is mounted on a vertical test rig (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Test rig.

Figure 8 shows the acquisition system that is controlled by a computer (PC) and records the information transmitted by the combined pressure/temperature sensor (TTP), the force sensor (TF) and the displacement sensor (Td). The measured parameters are:
the friction force between the two ‘U’ seals and the rod;
the temperature and the pressure in the test cell; and
the translational speed of the test cell.
Figure 8.
The experimental device scheme (PC, computer; TF, force transducer, DP, test cell; Td, displacement transducer; TTP, temperature and pressure transducer; M, manometer; Ss, direction valve; Sp, pressure valve, Pm, hand pump; and T, oil tank).

The results of the friction force measurements have the shape of a periodic variation in time at constant speed and constant input pressure. The friction force recorded is a mixture of friction forces from both seals. Because they are placed face-to-face in the test seal, one is experiencing instroke movement while the other is experiencing outstroke movement. Only the average values of the friction forces recorded during the outstroke movement of the test cell are used for comparisons with the numerical simulations. This is because, during this movement the rod and the test cell are better aligned and additional inertial forces recorded on the force transducer, placed on the rod, are avoided. Figure 9 represents the variation in time of the friction force at 80 mm/s and 10 MPa. Figure 9.
Typical recorded data at 10 MPa constant input pressure.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The experimental results are presented in terms of the friction force variation versus several important parameters and are systematically compared with the numerical predictions.

In order to study the fluid pressure effect on the rod-seal friction force, the friction forces at different input pressures has been recorded. The average value of friction obtained from each trace is plotted in Figures 10 and 11 against the input pressure for two different translation speeds varied by changing the flow rate of the hydraulic motor oil supply. The temperature in the test cell is 15 °C. The measured oil viscosity at this temperature is 0.1455 Pas. The pressure–viscosity coefficient α depends on temperature and in lack of experimental data is approximated by equation (7) given in Nikas14 (8)α=34.95·10(-9)+9.65·10(-9)·log10(μ0) at 15 °C, α = 0.0269 MPa−1. Figure 10.
Friction force variation with hydraulic pressure at 43 mm/s. Figure 11.
Friction force variation with hydraulic pressure at 75 mm/s.

As it can be observed in Figures 10 and 11, both experimental measurements and numerical predictions show an increase of the friction with the hydraulic pressure. At 75 mm/s the friction force increases linearly and there is a very good agreement between numerical and experimental results. At 43 mm/s the agreement is not very good and the measured force seems to have a non-linear variation with hydraulic pressure. Another important observation is that the most important contribution of the friction arises from the instroke displacement. During the outstroke, the hydraulic pressure does not influence the friction force.

Figure 12 shows the film thickness profile at two different translation speeds during an instroke and outstroke movements. It can be observed that during the instroke, the increase of the hydraulic pressure highly decreases the film thickness. The decrease of the film thickness leads to an increase of the friction force. The increase of the pressure (that due to the piezo-viscous effect increases the oil viscosity) also leads to an increase of the friction force. Therefore, the combined effect of the film thickness decrease and pressure increase explains the increasing of the friction force observed in Figures 10 and 11. During the outstroke, the increase of the hydraulic pressure is compensated by the increase of the film thickness, which explains why the friction force is almost constant. Figure 12.
Film thickness profile during instroke (a, b) and during outstroke (c, d) at U = 43 mm/s (a, c) and at U = 75 mm/s (b, d).

It is interesting to observe that at U = 75 mm/s the film thickness is generally greater than 0.1 µm (except for instroke at ph = 20 MPa). At U = 43 mm/s and for an instroke movement, the film thickness is generally lower than 0.1 µm (except at ph = 5 MPa). Figure 10 shows that the experimental measurements of the friction force does not match the numerical predictions, especially for hydraulic pressures greater than 10 MPa, when the predicted film thickness is lesser than 0.1 µm. Figure 11 shows a very good agreement between numerical and experimental results, except for ph = 20 MPa, when the film thickness during the instroke is smaller than 0.1 µm. It seems that if the film thickness is smaller than 0.1 µm, the numerical model overestimates the friction force.

An explanation is that the numerical results presented in this article correspond to an idealized hydrodynamic problem for smooth surfaces. When the thickness of the lubricant film is as low as the roughness asperity heights, the assumption of full-film hydrodynamic lubrication may be inadequate and mixed lubrication conditions must be included in the model. The roughness of the elastomeric seals were measured in a Taylor–Hobson optical (non-contacting) instrument. The average roughness of the seal Ra is 1.53 µm and the root mean square roughness Rq is 2.12 µm. These values are consequently higher than the film thickness predicted above. Theoretically, if mixed lubrication is included in the model, the results obtained for film thickness smaller than 1 µm must be very different from the results obtained by assuming smooth surface, but closer to the real functioning conditions. However, it seems that the idealized smooth surfaces model approach very well the experimental measurements if film thickness is higher than 0.1 µm. This result suggests that the roughness of the relatively soft seal (partially) disappears under the pressures in the sealed contact. It is interesting to observe that the average roughness of the rod is 0.12 µm and has higher influence over the friction force than the seal roughness.

From these results, it can be concluded that the IHL method is a useful and rapid approach to analyse and predict the friction force of hydraulic seals, even at very low film thickness. However, at very low translation speeds, when the film thickness decrease below a certain limit (in the presented case around 0.1 µm), the full film lubrication theory for smooth surfaces is not convenient to describe the lubrication of the seal contact. This is evident from Figure 13 that shows the variation of the friction force versus the translation speed. The numerical predictions are in good concordance with the measurements only at high translation speeds. Globally, the increase of the translation speed together with the increase of the hydraulic pressure increases the friction force. Further investigations need to be undertaken to check the agreement at different temperatures and with other rubber materials. Figure 13.
The variation of friction with the translation speed.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A numerical solution method for hydrodynamic lubrication problems of reciprocating elastomeric seals, based on the inverse lubrication theory, are compared with experimental results. The comparison concerns only the friction force, obtained for different hydraulic pressures varying from 5 up to 20 MPa and for different stroke velocities varying from 43 up to 80 mm/s. The test cell contained a couple of two HNBR ‘U’ rod seals and the recorded friction force is the combination of the outstroke friction of one seal and the instroke friction of the other seal.

The results show that the IHL method predicts well the experimental results for conditions where the film thickness is higher than 0.1 µm, which is very close to the rod roughness. This suggests that the roughness of the seal, which is initially around 1.53 µm, disappears under the pressures in the sealed contact and does not play an essential role in the lubrication mechanisms of this kind of hydraulic seal. For these conditions, it is shown that the model does not need to take into account the mixed lubrication conditions.

However, it is clear that for very small film thickness, the full film lubrication theory for smooth surfaces is not convenient. This may imply that in these conditions the shaft roughness is playing an essential role and mixed lubrication cannot be ignored. A second hypothesis is that adhesion phenomena, not taken into account by the lubrication theory, can appear in the contact areas.

sec.p: This study has been funded by the Sectorial Operational Programmed Human Resources Development 2007–2013 of the Romanian Ministry of Labour, Family and Social Protection through the Financial Agreement POSDRU/88/ 1.5/S/61178 and by the Technical Centre for the Mechanical Industry (CETIM) – Nantes.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the Sectorial Operational Programmed Human Resources Development 2007–2013 of the Romanian Ministry of Labour, Family and Social Protection through the Financial Agreement POSDRU/88/1.5/S/61178 and the Technical Centre for the Mechanical Industry (CETIM) – Nantes, for the financial support of this work. Also, the authors’ wish to thank INOE 2000 IHP, Bucharest, Romania for the support and technical assistance in performing this study.
